item.title: Dead Island 3 is Aiming to Release in 2028, Says Dambuster Studios
item.content:encoded:
In its new financial report, UK-based Dambuster Studios has reported that it is aiming to release Dead Island 3 by Q1/Q2 2028 (April – October 2028).

In the financial report (thanks, Timur222), it says that the primary focus for Dambuster Studios is now Dead Island 3, and all developers, who currently consist of 194 employees, will be assigned to the project once the Luna and Mac versions of Dead Island 2 are complete.

“Parts of the game [Dead Island 3] are now in early production with feature, character, world, and story design moving at pace,” says the report.

The release date suggests that the game will release for the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S|X, PC, and the next-generation of consoles, which are currently forecasted to release by the end fof 2028.

Dead Island 3 New Location

This isn’t the first time that we’ve heard of Dead Island 3 from Dambuster Studios, though.

Earlier this year, the studio celebrated 14 years since the original game debuted, with the studio revealing that the second game has accumulated an impressive 20 million players.

The post teased that the “journey” was far from over, accompanied by a photo showing a character leaving LA, suggesting that there will be a new location for the third game.

In July, a former Dead Island 2 developer addressed the calamities caused by the game’s delay, which saw its development cycle pushed out to around a decade, including studio swaps and abandoned deadlines.

Are you excited about Dead Island 3? Let us know on the Insider Gaming forum.

item.title: Infinity Ward Appears to Debunk Recent Modern Warfare 4 Leaks
item.content:encoded:
Recently, a claim surfaced on social media suggesting that 2026’s Modern Warfare 4, the rumored next release in the Call of Duty series, will be ‘a complete copy of Modern Warfare 2’ from 2022. It was suggested that the upcoming game’s multiplayer platform is a carbon copy of the 2022 title, right down to the ‘excessive visual recoil’ mechanics.

However, Infinity Ward recently signed off social media for the festive window, chiming in with a comment that directly flies in the face of this claim, prompting Call of Duty fans to lose their minds.

Is Modern Warfare 4 a Copy or Not?

TheGhostofHope, a reliable Call of Duty leaker, recently took to social media with a bombshell claim:

Modern Warfare 4 Multiplayer in its current state is currently a complete copy of Modern Warfare II except for no perk charging system and less ADS/slide penalties.

He expanded soon after:

There is A TON of visual recoil on weapons in Modern Warfare 4 just like Modern Warfare II. Like I said in my last tweet it’s pretty much a complete copy outside of a few little things.

Fans were quick to criticize the comments, while others revelled in the news. Modern Warfare 2’s multiplayer platform wasn’t that bad, all things considered.

However, in the days that followed, Infinity Ward snapped onto social media with a clear message:

Happy holidays everybody!

Wishing our community an awesome holiday season and looking forward to talking soon.

Don’t believe everything you read on the Internet.

See you in 2026.

The team is almost certainly disputing the recent Modern Warfare 4 claims, and TheGhostofHope was quick to respond as he came under fire:

TheGhostofHope’s followers rallied, suggesting that the leaker has ‘never been wrong’ about anything in the Call of Duty space.

What do you think? Do you believe Infinity Ward is trying to save face, or is Modern Warfare 4 genuinely a copy and paste of Modern Warfare 2? Let us know on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Fewer Than 0.1% of Escape from Tarkov Players Have Completed The Game
item.content:encoded:
Before Escape from Tarkov hit 1.0 on November 15, Battlestate Games professed how difficult it would be to ultimately complete the game’s new campaign. The crushing difficulty and lengthy challenges of the story mode added with 1.0 would push even the most talented players to their limits, and the latest numbers indicate they weren’t lying.

In a recent post on social media, Battlestate Games revealed that one million copies of the game have been sold since November 15, on top of the millions that were purchased before 1.0 was released.

They also shared that just 500 PMCs have completed the game, representing a drastically small minority.

Escape from Tarkov is the Hardest Game Ever Made

If you take the 500 PMCs that have successfully run through to the end of Escape from Tarkov since the one million copies were sold post-launch, you get 0.5% of players.

If we assume that at least five times as many copies were sold pre-launch, you drill down to fewer than 0.1% of players having completed the game. The numbers are rough, but as Battlestate Games has never been transparent with the figures, it’s the best we have to go on.

It’s important to stress that the Escape from Tarkov campaign has only been around for one month. In that time, the concept of completing it has been available to very few people, and casual players will likely spend months trying to conquer it.

On December 1st, Battlestate Games revealed that Tigz, a streamer, was the first person in the world to complete Escape from Tarkov, and in the days that followed, 500 more players managed to secure that accolade.

Now, in a new social post, the team has set up more numbers, alongside a celebration of one million sales post-launch and a new promo code (ONEMILLIONPLUS) for all players to enjoy.

But why is this important?

Escape from Tarkov has always been considered one of the toughest games ever made. It’s a punishing thing that breaks gamers every day, offering a soul-crushing gameplay loop that requires players to load up, run a raid, and hopefully make it out alive.

At any point, a single, well-placed bullet can end everything, stripping them of their progress and their equipment.

There are no maps, no markers, no guidance lines, and no hand-holding mechanics. It’s a brutal experience, and that’s why only 500 players in the world have managed to complete the game thus far.

The number proposed here is 0.1%, but it’s likely lower than that. Escape from Tarkov was on the market for almost a decade in alpha and beta states, and that’s assuming that it sold just five million copies in that time.

item.title: Escape from Tarkov Has Sold One Million Copies in One Month
item.content:encoded:
Battlestate Games has just shared the news that Escape from Tarkov, the spearhead extraction shooter, has sold one million copies since hitting 1.0 on November 15. The game underwent an overhaul in November, marking it as a fully released game, and since that happened, it has been going like gangbusters.

The team also revealed that players have spent a collective 15,410 years in the game since November 15, equivalent to over 200 million full raids on Customs.

Escape from Tarkov (Still) on Top

Escape from Tarkov is, in the eyes of many, the best extraction shooter ever made. It has stiff competition these days and more on the horizon, but regardless of what surfaces, it almost always remains the number one extraction game going. The most challenging threat the game has faced in recent years is ARC Raiders, but it’s still holding its own.

On November 15, Battlestate Games released the 1.0 update for Escape from Tarkov, bringing the game into a graduated state from the alpha and beta stages it sat in for almost a decade. With this full release having been logged, the team now looks to future projects, including new games, post-launch DLC, and even a console release.

To celebrate the one million milestone, Escape from Tarkov’s developers released a new promo code for all players to enjoy:

  • ONEMILLIONPLUS

It’s also important to stress that this is the first time Battlestate Games has shared sales figures for Escape from Tarkov. Over the years, estimations have been made, but the team has never been transparent about how many copies Tarkov has shipped.

This figure gives us an idea of how popular Escape from Tarkov has been since its release, but it doesn’t account for the (potentially) tens of millions of copies sold in the last decade.
